page.title: 06OLD BUILDINGS IN EDGEFIELD
page.content: The importance of farming historically is shown in the splendid 16th & 17th century farm buildings which still remain. Edgefield Hall has had many additions and alterations but the core is Tudor and the Tudor porch still stands. Old Hall Farm,reputed to have a priest's hole, is a substantial E- shaped building of the early 17th century, recently taken over as the base of a small wood-working industry. The Mount, The Pyghtles, and the building now used by Edgefield Pottery give an impression of great prosperity in the 16th & 17th centuries, but Canon Marcon's memoirs tell of great poverty in tiny labourers' cottages: he tells of doorways less than 5 feet high and vertical ladders leading to upper floors. Some of today's cottages were originally several dwellings now put together.
